title: Does it mean you have healed from narcissistic abuse if you don't feel the need to look on Quora? - Quora

response.answer_text: Does it mean you have healed from narcissistic abuse if you don't feel the need to look on Quora? My interest in reading and writing about NPD fell away at Christmas, like an old dress that fell into tatters when I took it into my hands. I thought possibly I was distracted by the holiday. But the holiday has come and gone, and now I think I'm done with the part of the journey that is about my own healing. As this is my second pass through hell, I know I will encounter a few boulders along my path that were blasted off Hell's mountain behind me and onto the roadway ahead. These are a reminder that nothing one meets in life is meant to be entirely left behind. Perhaps that was my mistake after N#1. I went through the grieving, the reflection, and the writing, after leaving N#1 in 2001. I left it behind me in 2004. I have arrived again at this juncture. I left N#2 in February 2017, and almost 3 years later, I feel, once again, that I have completed the course. This time, I plan to remain cognizant that it is only one course, and not the entire life lesson. This phenomenon--which we call narcissism--this energy which strives to trick and deceive, to lead astray, to break and to burn, our humanity, is here on this earth. This is not about one person who embodies this energy who is no longer a part of our lives. That is a part of it, sure. But more than that, it is about our awakening, and the awakening of humanity, to the wolves in sheep's clothing among us. It is about their goals, and their tactics, and their devastating effects. We only have to look at what is happening in our country (the U.S.) and in the world, to see that waking up to narcissism is not merely about healing from a bad relationship. So I will carry this understanding forward, and I will continue to read and learn and write, as I believe is my responsibility. Having failed this course once before, I surmise we have to honor our life lessons by passing them on. But I suspect this will be different for me now. Like the end of a long relationship, the end of my healing journey seemed sudden but wasn't. I was talking to my sister some weeks ago when I said, "I think I would like to paint again," surprising myself. I love how impulses rise up from the subconscious and find their way off the ends of our tongues. I lamented having given away my art supplies 15 years earlier when I'd moved into too small an apartment to accommodate them. At the time I’d told myself I didn’t want to paint anymore anyway. (I've since moved to a larger apartment.) My sister sent me an easel for my birthday. That was when I knew I was serious. I pulled that easel out of the box with all the wonder of a five-year-old child at Christmas. I unearthed and cleaned some brushes that hadn't been good enough to give away, dusted off a few canvases I’d spared “just in case.” Since then, I have been balancing and re-balancing my checkbook, searching for dollars to buy paint. I ordered some yesterday. At this same time, the most debilitating of my physical disabilities, acquired from my ex's abuse, appear to be moving into remission, with the encouragement of prayer, acupuncture, exercise and nerve supplements. For weeks, I doubted my decision to assemble the easel, and have it looming over my ruined arms, hands, legs and feet, like a cruel taunt. But I built it, and my numbed and burning limbs have come around, like the movie saying, "Build it and they will come."  So a new chapter for me, coming as soon as the paint arrives, but I will still be checking in on my dear and wonderful Quora friends. I hope to still sometimes have thoughts to add to the discourse. Writing, painting and friends. It’s a beautiful life. I wish all of you a happy new year.

The Short Answer: For many people, reading about other Quorans who were abused by people with narcissistic personality disorder has a good effect. People tell me that they benefit from: Learning that narcissistic abuse is a real thing.Finding out that they did not cause their mate’s problems, even though their mate blamed them.Reading other people’s stories and realizing that they are not alone.Feeling validated by the support they receive from other Quorans.For some people, being on Quora is an important stage in their healing. It is rarely sufficient to heal every wound, if these wounds go deep. In addition, many people who end up with a narcissistic mate have childhood issues that are still active in their life and need attention. So what might it mean if you no longer want to read about NPD on Quora? Most people who stop reading about narcissism and relationships have reached a tipping point. They are already going “no contact” with their ex or minimal contact with their narcissistic parents. They comprehend what happened and why. Now they tip over some invisible emotional edge and see their situation as past. They are ready to move into what for them is their next step in healing: going “no contact” with the topic of narcissism. Punchline: You know that you are healing from your narcissistic relationship when you start becoming bored reading about narcissists and narcissism. Some of us will continue reading and writing about NPD when it is no longer just motivated by our personal pain. In that case, it has become a genuine interest of ours and a fascinating topic to explore. A2A Elinor Greenberg, PhD, CGP In private practice in NYC and the author of the book: Borderline, Narcissistic, and Schizoid Adaptations. www.elinorgreenberg.com

The short answer is: MAYBE YES - MAYBE NO And that is a useless answer, but what you have to realize is heeling is not a binary thing. There is no definite cut off point. Certainly, no longer needing to find answers about your abuse is a BIG STEP. Does it mean you are 100% healed? NO But do you need or even WANT to be 100% healed, that would be wanting to be the same as before - I don’t want to be the same as before. I have learned a lot from this experience and YES I am more cautious of people and their intention. In light of what I now know is out there [narcissists] I concider that a good thing. But you could say that is not fully healing. Its all a big mess and its all open to interpretation - I would ask the question: ARE YOU HAPPY?ARE YOU THE PERSON YOU WANT TO BE?ARE YOU LOOKING FORWARD TO THE FUTURE?These are the questions that I would say are the important ones. If you can answer YES to all of them - then you are as healed as you NEED to be. If not, then no… I strongly recommend you learn about narcissism. A great place to start is The Pocket Encyclopaedia Of Narcissism. It has the highest ‘information density’ of any book on the subject, meaning it is just facts and examples, no filler, no padding. You will learn more, and understand more about narcissism and recovery per minute invested [in reading] than any other book out there. It covers everything from how narcissists are created to how to get them out of your life for good. How to spot the red flags and how to prevent them from targeting you in the first place. Links can be found in my Quora profile - just click my name at the top of this answer. Facebook Link Dating Harley Quinn FOOTNOTE Image attribution: Lee Miller (2019) or Royalty-free stock photography Quotation attribution/citation: Lee Miller (2019) The Pocket Encyclopaedia Of Narcissism Affiliation: Any book recommended in this answer was written by me Lee Miller

I rarely laugh reading anything here, but I laughed when I read this. Yes - if you don’t feel pulled back toward the well of analysis, you’re healing. Maybe not healed, but you’re doing better. I have a theory that you should front-load rumination, and do a lot of it ASAP, then wean yourself off of it in favor of constructively rebuilding your life. Periodic rumination is fine in the long run: consider how many people swear that going to AA for decades helped them stay clean. Nobody knows what “healed” means, anyway. I suspect it’s when you are able to treat the matter as a past injury and current weakness that’s good for a couple of laughs.

Yes & no. To be honest, this could be a sign to someone that they have moved on & done with dealing with Narc abuse. Some of us find a sense of community in supporting others in their journey, as we have been helped by others. If you are wanting to leave this site because you are healed & no longer interested, that’s positive. It’s all up to you.

Healing. IMHO ..I don’t ever see myself healed from having someone destroy my existence. When someone distorts you’re own mind, You lose a part of yourself that is irreplaceable. Due to that loss, I don’t see “ healed” as a possibility. I see surviving and thriving but never healed. I hope I’m wrong

You know. This is an excellent question. I have thought about, why when I’m busy or going out with a girl. I don’t feel any of the grief as intense. I constantly work on projects as a way to decompress. The more tired I am. The less i have to complain about. The is a saying. Idle hands are the devils hands. Or something like that. Sometimes I’ve gone a minute because I don’t have any shit to get out. However. This is a great platform for perspective, questions, life experience. Anytime I think how do I handle this. I ask a question for perspective. I think it is amazing for so many other benefits.
